image.altText: Jacinta Allan flanked by Vicki Ward and Ben Carroll standing in sunshine outdoors.

props.synopsis: Incoming Victorian premier Jacinta Allan says she will have more to say about a cabinet reshuffle in coming days, after she was elected unopposed by her party room. Follow all the action in our live blog.

title.children: 'Honour and privilege': Jacinta Allan to become Victoria's second female premier

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: When asked whether she would have the same hands-on management style that her predecessor had, she said more would be revealed in time. She indicated there would be some portfolio reshuffling and some changes in the "machinery of government" in the coming days and weeks. Ms Allan also acknowledged her place as Victoria's second ever female premier, and said women had a place to be recognised in roles all across the community. "I hope it in some way sends in some way a message to young women," she said. "Young women have talked to me about my journey and how they can learn from that — hopefully learn from some of the slings and arrows and not have it repeated — but also too how they can see leadership does come in different shapes and sizes and there is a place for women at every single table." Ms Allan was emotional when discussing that last part, wiping a tear away before moving onto the next question.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Portfolio shake-up on the way

children.content: When asked whether she would have the same hands-on management style that her predecessor had, she said more would be revealed in time.
She indicated there would be some portfolio reshuffling
and some changes in the "machinery of government" in the coming days and weeks.
Ms Allan also acknowledged her place as Victoria's second ever female premier, and said women had a place to be recognised in roles all across the community.
"I hope it in some way sends in some way a message to young women," she said.

"Young women have talked to me about my journey and how they can learn from that — hopefully learn from some of the slings and arrows and not have it repeated — but also too how they can see leadership does come in different shapes and sizes and there is a place for women at every single table."
Ms Allan was emotional when discussing that last part, wiping a tear away before moving onto the next question.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: She's flanked by her new deputy Ben Carroll and Member for Eltham Vicki Ward, who is poised to take up Ms Allan's role as Minister for Suburban Rail Loop. "It is such a deep honour and privilege to be in the position to be heading to Government House and to be sworn in as premier of Victoria," Ms Allan said. She paid tribute to the "strong, decisive" premiers that came before her in Steve Bracks, John Brumby and Daniel Andrews and pledged to work hard "each and every day".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New Victorian premier Jacinta Allan up now

children.content: She's flanked by her
new deputy Ben Carroll
and
Member for Eltham Vicki Ward
, who is poised to take up Ms Allan's role as Minister for Suburban Rail Loop.

props.alt: Jacinta Allan speaks in a garden.

children.content: Victoria's incoming premier Jacinta Allan (centre) spoke beside deputy Ben Carroll (right).
(ABC News)
"It is such a deep honour and privilege to be in the position to be heading to Government House and to be sworn in as premier of Victoria," Ms Allan said.
She paid tribute to the "strong, decisive" premiers that came before her in Steve Bracks, John Brumby and Daniel Andrews and pledged to work hard "each and every day".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jacinta Allan will make her first comments after being elected Labor leader. She will become Victoria's 49th Premier after Daniel Andrews officially resigns at 5pm today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Watch the press conference live

children.content: Jacinta Allan will make her first comments after being elected Labor leader.
She will become Victoria's 49th Premier after Daniel Andrews officially resigns at 5pm today.

image.altText: a blonde woman wearing glasses, a hard hat and a high-vis vest.

props.synopsis: Jacinta Allan has emerged from a Victorian Labor caucus meeting as the premier-elect, after long-time leader Daniel Andrews announced he was calling time on the job after nine years.

title.children: Jacinta Allan fends off late challenge to become 49th premier of Victoria

image.altText: Blue and white police tape at a crime scene.

props.synopsis: Police from Victoria's family violence unit are investigating the death of an 87-year-old woman, and a 91-year-old man who died in hospital.

title.children: Elderly man and woman dead after shooting in western Victoria

image.altText: Noel Pearson by AAP Lukas Coch

props.synopsis: Leading Yes campaigner and Indigenous academic Noel Pearson has made an impassioned speech to the National Press Club pleading for Australians to support the Voice to Parliament.

title.children: 'Only love can move us now': Pearson uses Voice as call for national unity

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a shirt and tie standing behind some microphones at a press conference

props.synopsis: Former regional Victorian MP Russell Northe will find out next month whether he will be jailed for using almost $180,000 of public money to fuel his gambling addiction.

title.children: Judge to decide whether imprisonment appropriate for former Morwell MP given mental illness

image.altText: A number of adults in protective headgear, surround a boy in a padded room preparing to grab him. All faces are blurred.

props.synopsis: The minister for the NDIS says an investigation may be needed following a Four Corners story that revealed children continued to be secluded in small, windowless rooms at a controversial autism service in Melbourne.

title.children: Shorten 'perplexed' controversial practices continued at Melbourne autism service

image.altText: A hand holds an electric vehicle charging plug against a car.

props.synopsis: The ombudsman says legislation that applies charges to drivers of electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles in Victoria — which remains the subject of a High Court challenge — is being "unfairly" administered.

title.children: Ombudsman finds Victoria's EV tax is being 'unfairly' administered

image.altText: Two young people walk through a train station wearing face masks.

props.synopsis: COVID-19 became one of Australia's leading causes of death in 2022, data from the Bureau of Statistics shows, however heart disease remained the biggest killer.

title.children: For the first time in over 50 years, an infectious disease is a leading cause of death in Australia

image.altText: man in bed smiling

props.synopsis: A friend of critically ill surfing great Mark Richardson says his situation has become so dire that medical evacuation is his only chance of survival.

title.children: Surfing great to be evacuated to Australia as friend warns 'he'll die if he stays'

image.altText: A hand holding a $100 note next to a wallet

props.synopsis: The annual rate of inflation jumped to 5.2 per cent in August, up from 4.9 per cent, on rising

title.children: Monthly inflation lifts to 5.2 per cent in August, up from 4.9 per cent, according to ABS

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair and a black jumper looks at the camera with a neutral expression

props.synopsis: A speech pathologist says Irabina Autism Services in Melbourne was running controversial practices as late as February last year.

title.children: Anica has seen a lot in her job, but this experience left her 'physically shaking'

image.altText: A man with brown hair and glasses stands in front of a train.

props.synopsis: Born in Williamstown and schooled in Wangaratta, the outgoing Victorian premier has made major decisions affecting regional communities during his time as state leader — and not all of them have made him popular.

title.children: As a 'kid from the country', what has Daniel Andrews done for regional Victoria?

image.altText: Daniel Andrews.

props.synopsis: Victoria's longest-serving – and Australia's highest-paid — premier is just hours from stepping down after more than 3,200 days leading the state. Here are the hits and misses of Daniel Andrews.

title.children: Daniel Andrews steps down as an undefeated leader. What were his legacies?

image.altText: Man wearing a suit and black jacket standing next to a wall.

props.synopsis: Victoria is in the grip of a heroin addiction problem. Experts say too few people are getting access to the treatment they need and that needs to change before fentanyl becomes a bigger issue in Australia.

title.children: Fentanyl has wreaked havoc in the United States. These experts worry Victoria could be next

image.altText: Nick Sallese and Margate road sign.

props.synopsis: A casual conversation at a tip-shop in Tasmania's south almost 15 years ago between a man not seen since 2008 and an acquaintance could be the missing clue a family has been desperately waiting for, the man's son says.

title.children: Nick has been missing for 15 years — a phone call has given his family new reason for hope

image.altText: Rescued Green Tree snake on fence

props.synopsis: Snake catchers say it is becoming harder to find new homes for the reptiles as urban areas expand and the weather warms up.

title.children: 'They're bigger and nastier': Warmer weather brings bumper start to snake season

image.altText: A drone image of a railway line under construction, with paddocks either side.

props.synopsis: Work on the multi-billion-dollar Inland Rail project slows significantly in Queensland, as an advocate warns the finished track may only stretch as far north as the state's border with New South Wales.

title.children: 'Father' of Inland Rail project from Melbourne to Brisbane warns line may never reach Toowoomba

image.altText: Woman coughing or sneezing into her elbow at her desk with laptop in front of her

props.synopsis: There aren't any vaccines for or anti-viral drugs to treat human metapneumovirus (HMPV), but experts say there's no need to be alarmed.

title.children: Have you been sick lately? It might be this virus you 'probably don't know about'

image.altText: Someone adjusts the oxygen mask of a tuberculosis patient who is lying in a hospital bed

props.synopsis: The state's health authorities says there is no link to a previous outbreak in the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara (APY) Lands and no risk to the wider community.

title.children: Five active tuberculosis cases identified in South Australia's Murraylands region, including young child

image.altText: A person walks past the PwC welcome sign inside a building.

props.synopsis: An independent review into governance, culture and accountability at consulting giant PwC has singled out the "excessive power" of the firm's chief executive and poor practices which went "unexamined and uncorrected" for years.

title.children: A scathing review into PwC's culture unearths a 'whatever it takes' attitude that resulted in 'integrity failures'

image.altText: Matt Raos during the inquiry sitting in front of a little microphone.

props.synopsis: Qatar Airways says the strip search was currently before the Federal Court so could not comment extensively but provided "assurance" that the incident was a "one off".

title.children: Qatar Airways says invasive strip search of female passengers was a 'one off'

image.altText: Donald Trump Ivanka, Melania, Barron, and Don Jr stand together looking solemn

props.synopsis: A New York judge has ruled that former US president Donald Trump committed fraud when he lied about his wealth for a decade, defrauding banks and insurers as he built his real estate empire. So what is his real net worth?

title.children: Donald Trump's latest legal loss won't send him to prison. But it's a major financial setback for him and his family

image.altText: Trump grimaces as he speaks at a rally outside in the hot sun, with sweat visible on his face.

props.synopsis: A judge rules that Donald Trump committed fraud for years while building the real estate empire that catapulted him to fame and the White House.

title.children: Donald Trump defrauded banks for years, New York civil case rules

image.altText: A man wearing a suit carrying a cup of coffee walks past a KPMG logo.

props.synopsis: KPMG's boss tells a Senate inquiry it's reviewing its donations process, PwC's internal bombshell drops, inflation is heating up again, and Qantas is facing a serious grilling by another inquiry.

title.children: Qantas grilled by Senate inquiry, as consulting firms KPMG and PwC face more heat

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Tony Sheldon is asking for "genuine contrition" from Qantas over its many documented problems. Which its chairman Richard Goyder says they do. That's as he faces calls to resign.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas says they have 'genuine contrition'

featuredLink.title: Qantas shareholders demand Richard Goyder quit as chairman as 'more things come to light' about management decisions

children.content: Senator Tony Sheldon is asking for "genuine
contrition" from Qantas over its many documented problems.
Which its chairman Richard Goyder says they do.
That's as he faces calls to resign.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There has been more zingers than sold at KFC. Senator Bridget McKenzie has been asking Qantas questions about when it agreed to support the "YES" campaign, including how long it takes to put a decal on a plane. (Apparently, a day? It was a little confusing and came down to paint.) The Senator also shut down CEO of Qantas Vanessa Hudson when she tried to tell the inquiry about the airline's reconciliation plan. "We all have reconciliation plans," the Senator replied. She also accused the airline of a "filibuster". There's been a lot of questions on notice so far.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas is facing an absolute grilling so far

children.content: There has been more zingers than sold at KFC.
Senator Bridget McKenzie has been asking Qantas questions about when it agreed to support the "YES" campaign, including how long it takes to put a decal on a plane.
(Apparently, a day? It was a little confusing and came down to paint.)
The Senator also shut down CEO of Qantas Vanessa Hudson when she tried to tell the inquiry about the airline's reconciliation plan.
"We all have reconciliation plans," the Senator replied.
She also accused the airline of a "filibuster".
There's been a lot of questions on notice so far.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An independent review into governance, culture and accountability at consulting giant PwC has singled out the "excessive power" of the firm's chief executive and poor practices which went "unexamined and uncorrected" for years. Without naming former chief executives Tom Seymour and Luke Sayers, who are no longer with the firm, the review found a "generally accepted view that the CEO 'runs the show' and there was a reluctance of partners to challenge the CEO even at a senior leadership levels". Read more from Peter Ryan .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A 'whatever it takes' attitude that resulted in PwC 'integrity failures'

featuredLink.title: A scathing review into PwC's culture unearths a 'whatever it takes' attitude that resulted in 'integrity failures'

children.content: An independent review into governance, culture and accountability at consulting giant PwC has singled out the "excessive power" of the firm's chief executive and poor practices which went "unexamined and uncorrected" for years.

Without naming former chief executives Tom Seymour and Luke Sayers, who are no longer with the firm, the review found a "generally accepted view that the CEO 'runs the show' and there was a reluctance of partners to challenge the CEO even at a senior leadership levels".
Read more from
Peter Ryan

image.altText: x-ray of duck laid out wings spread arrow imbedded in rear right side deep all the way into near it's left thigh bone

image.altText: A man walks on the street holding a plastic bag, which contains a bag of ice.

image.altText: Emmanuel Macron and his wife Brigitte Trogneux.

props.synopsis: Emmanuel Macron defied expectations in 2017 when he won the French presidency. Many say his self-belief was essential to his victory but it could also risk his global legacy.

title.children: Arrogance, charisma and 'the right path': The gift and the price of Emmanuel Macron's personality

image.altText: A bird's eye view of a concrete crossing over a small creek on green farmland lined with trees.

props.synopsis: Despite having little to do with the Voice, the blowing up of ancient rock shelters and a bungled attempt to preserve Aboriginal heritage are the issues shaping the referendum debate in WA.

title.children: How this banal concrete driveway became emblematic of WA's unique debate on the Voice
